text:
> The Master-level course is intended for students that have not seen Smalltalk before (I know, it’s crazy that they have not seen it and they are Master students :smile: ).
Warning: you are making the non-smalltakers more "intimidated"! :sweat_smile: :wink: :smile:  (or my not-so-good English understanding made me misunderstood what you said)

If I was younger I may have felt "ouch, I am graduated in Computer Science and I don't know Smalltalk, it is crazy".

I am not that young and know that there are lots of ways to become a real legitimate programmer, with Smalltalk or not. Let alone because SmallTalk is not used much in the industry.

That said, I really miss not <http://programmi.ng|programming> in Smalltalk and I see this Glam School as nice occasion to start this adventure! I guess I needed a kind of trigger.

So thanks <@U0135LTLDRU> for starting the subject and <@UE1JQM9HQ> for offering help! :relaxed:

text: My message was meant to be a joke :slightly_smiling_face:.

elements.text: My message was meant to be a joke

text: Yes, I know, I have seen the smiley! :wink: But I guess even as a joke it could be "intimidating".

elements.text: Yes, I know, I have seen the smiley!
But I guess even as a joke it could be "intimidating".

text: I apologize. That was not my intention :slightly_smiling_face:.

text: To support the idea that Smalltalk is not intimidating and that learning it can be fun, here is how you can experience learning the syntax. You can find it at the end of the Pharo 101 slideshow :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: To support the idea that Smalltalk is not intimidating and that learning it can be fun, here is how you can experience learning the syntax. You can find it at the end of the Pharo 101 slideshow

text: That'd be nice! But let's wait until we figure out what our first group activity is (other than this live session today), and then see how people do on that.

text:
Live session happening here, just starting now: <https://us02web.zoom.us/j/88608172723?pwd=bHJKc2M5QVA1YWdFWnUzdWs3SW1qQT09>

(It is also being recorded)

Edit — Thanks for the session today, Tudor! Very informative.

For a future session, I'd love to see a walkthrough of how you'd add `alt + left arrow` and `alt + right arrow` to skip by word in the editor (which is a standard feature of OSX text editors). It was fun to catch a glimpse of how to traverse the in-terms-of-itself implementation of GT, but it was hard to get a sense of how you'd actually use that to work on a real system.

elements.text: Live session happening here, just starting now:

(It is also being recorded)

Edit — Thanks for the session today, Tudor! Very informative.

For a future session, I'd love to see a walkthrough of how you'd add
alt + left arrow
and
alt + right arrow

to skip by word in the editor (which is a standard feature of OSX text editors). It was fun to catch a glimpse of how to traverse the in-terms-of-itself implementation of GT, but it was hard to get a sense of how you'd actually use that to work on a real system.

text: I’m similarly wondering how modifiable the system is. It seems like you could delve deep into the internals and change anything. (Which is cool! And scary.)

elements.text: I’m similarly wondering how modifiable the system is. It seems like you could delve deep into the internals and change anything. (Which is cool! And scary.)

text: Thanks a lot Tudor for the presentation! It was very interesting. I love the idea of discoverable *and* moldable programming environment.

elements.text: Thanks a lot Tudor for the presentation! It was very interesting. I love the idea of discoverable
and
moldable programming environment.

text: <@UE1JQM9HQ> as a fellow academic, I would also be interested in learning about how your research experience informed the design of GT. I’m doing research at the intersection of programming tools and HCI, and I’m always looking for examples of how to bridge academia <-> industry.

elements.text: as a fellow academic, I would also be interested in learning about how your research experience informed the design of GT. I’m doing research at the intersection of programming tools and HCI, and I’m always looking for examples of how to bridge academia <-> industry.

text: Certainly. Just know that I am available to hold a session. Feel free to just organize one.

elements.text: Certainly. Just know that I am available to hold a session. Feel free to just organize one.

text: Couldn't make it in the end :sob: Is the recording likely to be up soon?

elements.text: Couldn't make it in the end
Is the recording likely to be up soon?

text: It will be up in the next couple of days

elements.text: It will be up in the next couple of days

text: You can indeed modify everything down to the internals. Like with any Smalltalk system BTW. There is however a difference between "designed to be modifiable" (and thus easy to modify) and "accidentally modifiable" (you have to figure out for yourself how to do it).

elements.text: You can indeed modify everything down to the internals. Like with any Smalltalk system BTW. There is however a difference between "designed to be modifiable" (and thus easy to modify) and "accidentally modifiable" (you have to figure out for yourself how to do it).
